author: .vbuterin
content:
> So two other ideas I had. Both involve doing (2), charging *at time of execution*, but then solving the backwards compatibility issue in a different way.
> 
> 1. Replace the 63/64 constant with 3/4. This way if you have a transaction that requires a computation and then some "post-failure" work in case the inner computation fails, you can still do it with the remaining 1/4.
> 2. Allow the transaction sender themselves to select the above constant, or possibly even allow the transaction sender to supply a gas budget per contract as part of the transaction
> 
> The principle behind the second idea is that ultimately the party that would lose money if an internal call "betrays" them is the sender themselves, so the sender should choose which addresses to trust

author: pipermerriam
content: I've been trying to think about this like python context managers. For the meta transaction use case the two are very similar. To preserve meta transactions we would need the ability to guarantee the execution of the code in the exit block (but that unfortunately depends on the execution of the external call which is the equivalent of the code from the python context block). I don't have any breakthrough ideas but the mental model at least helps understand the behavior  we're trying to preserve.
